qas.question: What shape are the bundles in the young stem of dicotyledons arranged in?
What is a layer of meristem or formative tissue known as?
What results from the development of xylem on the inside and phloem on the outside?
What's another name for the concentric rings in trees?
What is formed  when a layer of dicotyledons is formed between the bundles?

plausible_answers.text: the development of xylem on the inside and phloem on the outside

qas.question: What causes a regular increase in young stems?

plausible_answers.text: the hard wood persists and forms the bulk of the stem and branches of the woody perennial

qas.question: What happens when the annual rings are crushed?
How is soft phloem marked for each growth season?
How are bundles in young stems arranged in branches?

context: In the dicotyledons, the bundles in the very young stem are arranged <b9_0>in <a0_0>an open ring<b9_0/><a0_0/>, separating a central pith from an outer cortex. In each bundle, separating the <a1_0>xylem and phloem<a1_0/>, is a layer of meristem or active formative tissue known as <a2_0>cambium<a2_0/>. By the formation of a layer of cambium between the bundles (interfascicular cambium), <b5_0>a complete ring<b5_0/> is formed, and a regular periodical <a3_0>increase in thickness<a3_0/> results from <b6_0>the development of xylem on the inside and phloem on the outside<b6_0/>. The soft phloem becomes crushed, but <b7_0>the hard wood persists and forms the bulk of the stem and branches of the woody perennial<b7_0/>. Owing to differences in the character of the elements produced at the beginning and end of the season, the wood is marked out in transverse section <b8_0>into concentric rings<b8_0/>, one for each season of growth, called <a4_0>annual rings<a4_0/>.
